proposed_definition: A nutrient adaptation in which an organism is capable of growth and survival in environments with very low nutrient concentrations, typically exhibiting slow growth rates and efficient nutrient uptake systems.
reasoning: This definition follows the genus-differentia form starting with the parent class 'nutrient adaptation'. It distinguishes oligotrophs from copiotrophs (prefer high nutrient concentrations) by specifying adaptation to low-nutrient environments and associated characteristics (slow growth, efficient uptake). Oligotrophs are ecologically important in nutrient-poor habitats like deep ocean waters and oligotrophic lakes.
